misconceptions.name: Hard-coding the grade instead of reading from the user
misconceptions.description: The student assigns a fixed value to the grade variable instead of reading the numeric grade from keyboard input as required. This means the program always computes a letter grade for 95 and never uses user-provided data.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can just assign a value like 95 to the grade variable instead of reading it from the user, and that satisfies the requirement to process a grade.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should prompt the user and read the numeric grade using the Scanner (e.g., int grade = input.nextInt();), so it works correctly for any grade the user enters.
symptoms: The program never calls Scanner methods (like nextInt) to read the grade.
The grade is always set to 95, so the output does not depend on user input.
The distance-input Scanner code is unrelated to the grading task.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misinterpretation of the problem requirements or confusion between example/test values and actual user input.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the hard-coded assignment with reading from the Scanner: prompt the user with "Enter grade:" and then use something like int grade = input.nextInt(); before the conditional logic.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The only grade value in the program is a constant (95), and no input method is used for grade, despite the clear requirement to read it.

evidence.snippet:
System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + distance);

        int grade = 95;
evidence.note: The grade is hard-coded to 95, and no input is read for the grade, contradicting the requirement to read a numeric grade from the user.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Using separate overlapping if statements instead of mutually exclusive conditions
misconceptions.description: The student uses multiple independent if statements for overlapping grade ranges. For a high grade (e.g., 95), several conditions are true, causing multiple letter grades (A, B, C, D) to be printed instead of exactly one.
misconceptions.student_belief: Writing multiple if statements like if (grade >= 90) for A, if (grade >= 80) for B, etc., will result in only the intended single letter grade being printed.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For mutually exclusive grade ranges, the conditions must either be structured with else-if/else or use non-overlapping Boolean ranges so that exactly one branch executes for any given grade.
symptoms: All grade conditions use only lower bounds (>= 90, >= 80, >= 70, >= 60) and are written as standalone if statements.
For grade = 95, the program would output A, then B, then C, then D on separate lines.
The logic does not ensure exactly one letter grade is printed for a given numeric grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: Incomplete understanding of how multiple if statements with overlapping conditions interact, and of how to design mutually exclusive conditional branches.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Use an if–else if–else chain, e.g., if (grade >= 90) { ... } else if (grade >= 80) { ... } else if (grade >= 70) { ... } else if (grade >= 60) { ... } else { ... }, or explicitly make the ranges non-overlapping with upper and lower bounds.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The pattern of five independent if statements with overlapping lower-bound checks strongly indicates a misunderstanding of mutually exclusive condition design.

evidence.note: Separate if statements with overlapping conditions mean that for grade 95, multiple branches (A, B, C, D) will all execute, indicating misunderstanding of mutually exclusive conditional logic.

misconceptions.name: Hardcoded Input Value
misconceptions.description: The student failed to read the numeric grade from the user input as required by the prompt. Instead, they hardcoded a static value (`int grade = 95;`), suggesting a misunderstanding of how to use the available `Scanner` object for this specific input.
misconceptions.student_belief: Input requirements can be satisfied by testing with a hardcoded value, or the student forgot to replace the test value with actual input reading.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The grade must be read using `input.nextInt()` or `input.nextDouble()` to satisfy the requirement of 'Write a program that reads a numeric grade (0-100)'.
symptoms: The program always produces the same output regardless of user interaction (if it were allowed to run the required logic correctly)
misconceptions.root_cause: Misinterpreting the input requirement of the problem statement.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace `int grade = 95;` with an instruction to prompt the user and read the input using the `Scanner` object.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code explicitly uses `int grade = 95;` where input was required. This is a direct contradiction of the prompt.

evidence.note: The grade is hardcoded to 95 instead of being read from the initialized Scanner.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Flawed Conditional Chain for Mutually Exclusive Ranges
misconceptions.description: The student used independent `if` statements for checking mutually exclusive grade ranges (A, B, C, D). This leads to cascading execution, where if a grade satisfies the highest threshold (e.g., 95), it consequently satisfies all lower thresholds (`>= 80`, `>= 70`, `>= 60`), causing the program to print multiple letter grades (e.g., A, B, C, D).
misconceptions.student_belief: Each statement executes whether or not the previous one was true, and that checking the lower bound (e.g., `>= 80`) is sufficient even when a higher bound was already met.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Mutually exclusive conditions, like grade ranges, must be checked using chained `if-else if-else` logic or by combining range boundaries using the logical AND operator (`&&`).
symptoms: Multiple letters (A, B, C, D) are printed for a single high grade input.
The logic fails to implement the strict ranges (e.g., B is 80-89, not >= 80).
misconceptions.root_cause: Lack of understanding of the consequences of using independent `if` statements versus `if-else if` for control flow branches where only one path should be taken.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Use `else if` between conditions or compound boolean expressions (`&&`) to ensure that only one block is executed.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The structure of sequential `if` statements clearly demonstrates this failure in control flow logic.

evidence.note: Five independent 'if' checks are used instead of a chained 'if/else-if' structure, resulting in cascading prints.

misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: Missing Required Output Prefix (Formatting)
misconceptions.description: The student failed to include the required output prefix 'Letter grade: ' in their final presentation, as shown in the Sample Run. This suggests a failure to follow the exact output formatting specification.
misconceptions.student_belief: Only the letter grade needs to be printed, and context text is optional.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The output must exactly match the format shown in the sample run.
symptoms: Output is just 'A' instead of 'Letter grade: A'
misconceptions.root_cause: Lack of attention to output requirements/formatting in the problem statement.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Ensure the print statement includes the full required string, such as `System.out.println("Letter grade: A");`.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The student consistently uses `System.out.println("A")` without the required prefix 'Letter grade: '. This is observable throughout lines 22-26.

evidence.note: Prints only 'A' missing the required 'Letter grade: ' prefix.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Incorrect use of non-exclusive if statements for mutually exclusive conditions
misconceptions.description: The student uses sequential if statements without else-if or else, causing multiple conditions to evaluate and print multiple letter grades instead of just one. When grade=95, the code prints 'A', 'B', 'C', and 'D' because all conditions (>=90, >=80, >=70, >=60) are true.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that using multiple independent if statements will correctly select and print only one letter grade based on the grade value.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: When conditions are mutually exclusive (only one can be true at a time in the logical flow), use if-else-if-else chains or else statements. This ensures only one branch executes. For grade ranges: if (grade >= 90) ... else if (grade >= 80) ... else if (grade >= 70) ... else if (grade >= 60) ... else ...
symptoms: Multiple letter grades are printed for a single input (e.g., 'A', 'B', 'C', 'D' all print when grade=95)
Output doesn't match the expected single letter grade
The control flow doesn't exit after finding a match
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding of how if statements work in sequence. The student may not realize that without else, all if conditions are independently evaluated, not treated as mutually exclusive branches.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the sequential if statements with an if-else-if-else chain: if (grade >= 90) { ... } else if (grade >= 80) { ... } else if (grade >= 70) { ... } else if (grade >= 60) { ... } else { ... }. The else-if structure ensures only one branch executes.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: High confidence because the code explicitly demonstrates the pattern of multiple independent if statements that would all evaluate to true for a grade of 95. This is a clear semantic error that directly contradicts the requirement to print only one letter grade.

evidence.note: All five if statements are independent. For grade=95, all conditions except the last are true, so A, B, C, and D all print instead of just A.

misconceptions.name: Hardcoded test value instead of reading user input
misconceptions.description: The student hardcodes the grade as 95 instead of reading it from keyboard input as specified in the requirements. The program has the infrastructure to read input (Scanner object created) but doesn't use it for the grade value.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that hardcoding a test value is acceptable or perhaps tested the logic with a fixed value and forgot to replace it with the actual input reading logic.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must read the numeric grade from keyboard input using Scanner, as specified in the requirements (reads a numeric grade) and demonstrated in the sample run prompt Enter grade: 85. Use: int grade = input.nextInt(); with an appropriate prompt message.
symptoms: The program doesn't prompt the user to enter a grade
The program always uses the hardcoded value 95 regardless of user input
The Scanner object is created but not used to read the grade
misconceptions.root_cause: The student may have been testing with a fixed value and forgot to implement the actual input reading, or misunderstood that the assignment requires dynamic user input.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace int grade = 95; with System.out.print("Enter grade: "); int grade = input.nextInt(); to read the grade from user input as shown in the sample run.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Extremely high confidence. The requirement explicitly states reads a numeric grade and the sample run shows Enter grade: 85. The code hardcodes int grade = 95; instead of reading input, which is a direct violation of the requirements.

evidence.note: Grade is hardcoded to 95 instead of being read from user input via Scanner.
Scanner object is created but never used to read the grade value.

misconceptions.name: Using a hardcoded grade instead of reading user input
misconceptions.description: The program never reads the numeric grade from the user. Instead, it assigns a fixed value (95) to the grade variable, so the letter-grade logic cannot be used for arbitrary user-supplied grades.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can just set grade = 95 directly instead of reading the grade value from the keyboard.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should prompt the user for a numeric grade and read it from the keyboard using Scanner (e.g., input.nextInt()), so the user can enter any grade between 0 and 100.
symptoms: The variable grade is assigned a literal constant 95 instead of being read from Scanner.
The user is never asked to enter a grade; only point coordinates are read.
The program always computes the letter grade for 95, regardless of any user input.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misinterpretation of the problem requirement to "read a numeric grade" or confusion between using constants and user input.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the hardcoded assignment int grade = 95; with a prompt and input, such as System.out.print("Enter grade: "); int grade = input.nextInt();
related_concepts: Separating different problems into different programs
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code clearly uses Scanner for other values but assigns a literal 95 to grade and never reads a grade from the user.

evidence.snippet:
System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + distance);

int grade = 95;
evidence.note: The grade variable is set to a fixed constant 95 rather than being read from input, so the program does not actually read a numeric grade from the user.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Using independent if statements for overlapping grade ranges
misconceptions.description: The student uses a sequence of independent if statements with only lower-bound checks (grade >= 90, grade >= 80, etc.) instead of mutually exclusive ranges or an if-else-if chain. For a high grade like 95, multiple conditions are true, so the program prints multiple letter grades (A, B, C, D) instead of exactly one.
misconceptions.student_belief: Checking each grade threshold with a separate if statement (grade >= 90, grade >= 80, etc.) is enough to select the correct single letter grade.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Because the grade ranges are overlapping, you must either (1) use mutually exclusive conditions, e.g., grade >= 90, grade >= 80 && grade < 90, etc., or (2) use an if-else-if chain so that only the first matching condition runs. Otherwise, one grade value can trigger multiple outputs.
symptoms: For grade = 95, all of the conditions grade >= 90, grade >= 80, grade >= 70, and grade >= 60 are true.
The program will print multiple lines: A, B, C, and D for a single grade.
There is no use of else or else-if to prevent multiple branches from executing.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding of how overlapping conditions and independent if statements interact, and how to design mutually exclusive boolean ranges for classification problems.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code uses a series of plain if statements with only lower bounds, and for grade = 95, four of the five conditions are clearly true. This will deterministically produce multiple letter outputs.

evidence.note: Each grade range is checked with a separate if and only a lower bound, so for grade = 95 all conditions except grade < 60 are true, leading to multiple letters printed.

misconceptions.name: Ignoring or failing to implement required input/output
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a completely different, irrelevant program (distance calculation) instead of the required 'Grade Calculator'. Although they include some hardcoded grade calculations, they do not read the required 'grade' input from the keyboard as specified in the prompt and rubric.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student implemented a solution for a previous or unrelated problem (Distance Between Points) in the code area designated for the Grade Calculator task, thus failing to meet the core input requirement.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must prompt the user for a single numeric grade (0-100) and read that input using the Scanner object for use in the grading logic.
symptoms: Code reads inputs for x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of 'grade'
The class name is 'DistanceBetweenPoints'
The core logic calculates distance, not grade
misconceptions.root_cause: Major misinterpretation of the problem requirements or failure to replace placeholder code/code from a previous task.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Delete all code pertaining to distance calculation. Implement the logic for the Grade Calculator, starting by prompting the user for the numeric grade and using `input.nextInt()`.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program is dedicated to calculating distance, which is not the assigned task (Q3: Grade Calculator). This is undeniable evidence of misinterpreting or swapping the assignment requirements.

evidence.note: Class name reflects an unrelated problem.
The code reads inputs for distance calculation (x1, y1, x2, y2), not the grade.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Incorrect use of chained conditionals (lack of 'else')
misconceptions.description: The student uses independent `if` statements instead of `if-else if` constructs. When checking for high grades like A (>=90) and B (>=80), a grade of 95 satisfies all conditions (>=90, >=80, >=70, >=60), resulting in multiple letter grades ('A', 'B', 'C', 'D') being printed for a single input.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that independent `if` statements work the same way as mutually exclusive checks (like `if-else if-else`) for range determination in linear grading systems.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Grade calculation requires mutually exclusive ranges. Since the ranges overlap when evaluated sequentially (e.g., 90 is also >=80), `else if` must be used to ensure only one branch executes.
symptoms: Multiple outputs are printed for a single input (e.g., 'A', 'B', 'C', 'D' for a grade of 95)
Use of only independent `if` statements in sequential checks
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding how conditional execution flow is controlled by `if` vs `if-else if` constructs, leading to logical errors in range evaluation.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the independent `if` statements with a single `if-else if` structure to ensure that once a grade range is matched (e.g., A), the subsequent checks (B, C, D) are skipped.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The structure clearly uses five independent `if` statements where `if-else if-else` is required for this type of range check, leading to incorrect, redundant output based on the logic shown.

evidence.note: Sequential independent 'if' statements result in catastrophic logical error, printing A, B, C, and D for grade=95.

misconceptions.name: Hardcoded value instead of reading user input
misconceptions.description: The student hardcoded the grade value as 95 instead of reading it from the user via Scanner input. The program ignores user input for the grade and uses a fixed value.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that hardcoding a test value (95) satisfies the requirement to read a numeric grade from the user.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must use Scanner to read a numeric grade from keyboard input, not hardcode a fixed value. Example: int grade = input.nextInt();
symptoms: Program does not prompt user for a grade value
Grade is always fixed at 95 regardless of user input
User cannot test different grade values
misconceptions.root_cause: Student may have written the code to test the logic with a hardcoded value and forgot to implement the actual input reading requirement.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Add a Scanner input line to read the grade: int grade = input.nextInt(); and remove the hardcoded int grade = 95;
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code explicitly shows 'int grade = 95;' which is a hardcoded literal value, and the program structure does not include any user input for grades.

evidence.note: Grade is hardcoded to 95 instead of being read from user input via Scanner

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Overlapping if conditions without else-if structure
misconceptions.description: The student uses multiple independent if statements to check ranges instead of else-if. This causes multiple conditions to execute for the same value. For grade 95, both 'A' and 'B' will print because 95 >= 90 AND 95 >= 80 are both true.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that sequential if statements will automatically exclude previous conditions, producing only one output.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: When checking multiple mutually exclusive ranges, use else-if statements so only one branch executes. Alternatively, check upper bounds with 'grade >= 90 && grade < 100' or use else-if: if (grade >= 90) {...} else if (grade >= 80) {...}
symptoms: Multiple letter grades print for a single input (e.g., both A and B print)
Output does not match expected single-letter grade
All conditions with grade >= X execute if that condition is true
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding of conditional control flow—not recognizing that independent if statements all execute independently rather than being mutually exclusive.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Change to else-if structure: if (grade >= 90) {...} else if (grade >= 80) {...} else if (grade >= 70) {...}
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code explicitly shows 5 independent if statements checking grade ranges. For any grade >= 60, multiple conditions will be true and multiple outputs will execute.

evidence.note: Using independent if statements instead of else-if causes overlapping conditions to all execute. For grade=95, both conditions 'grade >= 90' and 'grade >= 80' are true, resulting in both 'A' and 'B' printing.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for C and D
misconceptions.name: Overlapping if conditions for C and D ranges
misconceptions.description: The conditions for C (grade >= 70) and D (grade >= 60) also overlap with all higher grades due to the independent if statement structure. This is part of the same control flow misconception.
misconceptions.student_belief: Independent if statements will naturally exclude previous matches.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Use else-if to ensure only one grade bracket is matched and executed.
symptoms: For any grade >= 70, both C and D print
Multiple outputs for single input
misconceptions.root_cause: Same as A/B issue—not understanding that independent if statements do not create mutually exclusive branches.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Clear evidence in code structure showing independent if statements for overlapping conditions.

evidence.note: For grade >= 70, both conditions are true and both C and D will print
